page.title: 03Ecology of the Raveley area
page.content: The area is mainly arable farmland. Moorend Wood, Great Raveley is an ancient ash oak woodland with invasive Elm which has largely been killed by Dutch Elm Disease. It is owned and managed by the Beds and Hunts Trust for Wildlife, a conservation group who open it to the public once a year. It is the only Northern Cambridgeshire site of wood speedwell (Veronica Montana) which is found growing along the rides and the spindle tree (Euonymus Europeus) is also found. An old moat is inhabitied by grass snakes and wild fowl. The wood was surveyed by Oliver Rackham and the survey card is illustrated in his book 'Ancient Woodland'. Footpaths link the villages within the area. There is little polution.
